item.title: The rich one, the ‘boring’ one and Trump’s buddy: Key U.K. election players
item.description: Keir Starmer’s Labour appears poised to oust Rishi Sunak’s Conservatives from 14 years in power in the U.K. general election, with smaller parties also jostling for influence.

item.title: Pakistan arming JF-17 jets with Ra'ad nuke missiles
item.description: A recent image from the 2023 Pakistan Day Parade rehearsals revealed a JF-17 Thunder Block II aircraft carrying a Ra'ad-I air-launched cruise missile, marking its first public observation. This indicates Pakistan's progress in equipping JF-17s for nuclear capabilities, potentially replacing the ageing Mirage III/Vs. The development occurs amid regional nuclear arms competition and heightened tensions between Pakistan, India, and China.

item.title: Taiwan says China seizes fishing boat near its coast
item.description: China views democratically governed Taiwan as its own territory and has ramped up pressure on Taipei since May when President Lai Ching-te took office, a man Beijing accuses of being a "separatist".

item.title: Russia's largest Black Sea Port under drone attack, beaches closed for safety
item.description: The mayor of Novorossiysk announced restricted beach access due to a sea drone attack repelled by Russian defence forces. Two sea drones were destroyed near the crucial Black Sea port, a key oil export hub. The Russian defence ministry also reported downing 10 Ukrainian drones. Kyiv claims these attacks are retaliation for Russia's ongoing invasion of Ukraine since 2022.

item.title: A tale of two elections: how angry voters in France and UK turned on their leaders
item.description:
The countries are heading in different directions, but voters on both sides of the Channel have similar concerns

It was raining in Calais on election day. A thin, penetrating, miserable drizzle blowing in off the Channel that was entirely in keeping with the mood of a great many voters as they headed to the polls in France’s most momentous ballot in living memory.

“It’s all going to shit,” said Xavier Hembert, voting with his son Arthur on the rue Philippine de Hainaut, named after Edward III of England’s French-born wife, much loved here ever since she persuaded him not to decapitate the port’s Burghers in 1347.

Continue reading...

item.title: Labour condemns harassment of its candidates and in pro-Palestinian areas
item.description:
Yvette Cooper warns of intimidation of would-be MPs and volunteers over party’s stance on Gaza

  • UK election live – latest updates

Yvette Cooper has condemned the harassment of Labour candidates and canvassers, amid reports of intimidation in pro-Palestinian areas across the country.

The shadow home secretary warned about “intimidation, abuse and harassment”, as pro-Palestinian activists in seats including Bethnal Green and Birmingham Ladywood clash with Labour supporters.

Continue reading...
